In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(text, ' ')
    lines = String[]

    current_line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line * " $word") <= text_width
            push!(lines, current_line * " $word")
            current_line = ""
        else
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = "$word"
        end
    end

    if !isempty(current_line)
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end

    return join(lines, '\n')
end
```
The function `wrap_string` takes a string `text::AbstractString`, and an optional keyword argument `text_width::Int = 10`. It splits the text into words, then iterates over each word. For every new word, it checks whether adding this word to the current line would result in a line longer than the allowed width. If not, it adds the word to the current line and continues with the next word. If adding the word to the current line would exceed the width, it adds the current line to the list of lines and starts a new line with only this word. Finally, if there's any remaining text in the current line (i.e., after all words have been processed), it adds that final line to the list of lines. The function then returns a string consisting of all lines joined by newline characters (`'\n'`).

Example usage:
```julia
text = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed ac diam nec purus mollis dictum in at sem."
print(wrap_string(text))
```
This will print:
```
Lorem ipsum
dolor sit 
amet, 
consectetur
adipiscing 
elit. Sed
ac diam nec 
purus mollis 
dictum in at 
sem.
```
